The key to sustained, stable chain reactions is the fact that some of the fission neutrons generated are delayed by as much as a few milliseconds.  That transforms the "knife edge balance" problem into a trivial control problem.  Well, that and the design of the reactor to only achieve criticality with thermal neutrons, i.e. neutrons moving as slowly as a hydrogen atom at room temperature.  The probability of a neutron causing a fission is maximum at such low energy, and drops dramatically with increasing neutron energy.  So reactors have to employ a moderator, to slow down the fission neutrons - something like hydrogen (as in water) or carbon (as in graphite).  It's best not to use both, or you get a Chernobyl situation, just FYI.

Operating a nuclear reactor is not a balancing act between stoping the chain reaction and a bomb/Chernobyl. When uranium splits through fission some neutrons are released immediately, these are called prompt neutrons, and others are released seconds to minutes later, these are called delayed neutrons. By operating a reactor so that is only critical, maintaining constant fission rate, with the contribution of delayed neutrons, changes in reactor power happen on a long enough time scale to be controlled. Additionally, reactors are designed to take advantage of physical processes and properties of material that provide feedback to reactor power.  For example, increasing power raises coolant temperature, which decrease coolant  density. Since commercial water cooled reactors also use water to slow down high energy neutrons to the ideal energy for causing fission, decreasing the density of the water also reduces the number of neutrons available to cause a new fission event. This is called negative temperature feedback and is part of all current US commercial reactor designs.

Nuclear fission is sort of like balancing on a knife’s edge, as you put it. However, for anyone who doesn’t have a good understanding of nuclear power generation, its important to point out that in the case of a reactor core, this seemingly terrifying “knife’s edge”, where too many neutrons can cause a nuclear explosion, isn’t actually possible. There are two main reasons for this;

1) Fuel-grade Uranium is nowhere near enriched enough to sustain a runaway supercritical nuclear reaction that results in a nuclear explosion. Weapons-grade Uranium must be enriched to about 90% U-235 for a bomb to be possible. Fuel-grade Uranium is only enriched to around 3% U-235. Therefore, there just aren’t enough fissionable nuclei present in a fuel rod for this to occur.

2) Nuclear fuel rods, by virtue of being shaped as elongated rods, have way too much surface area for neutrons to escape the fissile material before triggering too many more fissions. For this very reason, a bomb core has to be a near-perfect sphere in order for it to actually work (in addition to being above the supercritical mass for the Uranium or Plutonium used). So even if the Uranium in a reactor core were weapons-grade (it never would be), and even if the neutrons were perfectly moderated (slowed down to maximize the probability of triggering more fissions, and hence releasing more neutrons), the fact that the fuel rods are rods completely ruins any possibility of the core ever acting as a bomb (and thankfully so!).

Anyway, I just thought I’d add this information just so that nobody gets the false idea that the knife’s edge analogy means that nuclear power reactors are just one mistake away from being a potential nuke, which is impossible.

The reason everybody was asking Einstein et al this question in 1933 was the Cockcroft-Walton accelerator experiment in 1932 in which the nucleus HAD been shattered at will: Li-7 hit by a high energy proton from an accelerator gives two alphas and MORE energy than went in (they used this to test E=mc^2 to good accuracy for the first time). So Einstein knew it could be done with protons, but remarked it was "like shooting at birds at night with a shotgun, on a night were there are very few birds." You couldn't get your energy back. It was a lot like nuclear FUSION which of course we think WILL BE possible commercially without neutrons. It's just hard to compressed the number of "birds." Einstein probably had a good idea of where the sun gets its energy even with no neutrons-- that had been guessed since 1920. He just didn't think people could compress things like we do now with our fusion machines.

Li-7 is a total aberration. There aren't any other isotopes vulnerable to protons, and it doesn't produce protons, but well-bound alphas. Szilard had just read an article about the Cockcroft-Walton experiment and the various commentaries on it by Einstein, etc., but he knew about the just-discovered neutron (1932), and wondered if there any isotopes which, if hit by neutrons, would undergo a simple reaction to produce more. There aren't. Fission (the only reaction that does this) hadn't been discovered, yet. Szilard spent five years looking for the right light isotope until fission was discovered in 1938 and then he realized this might be the reaction he was looking for, if it only produced neutrons (nobody knew). Szilard got them to measure this, and voila! Fission did produce excess neutrons. So then he knew.

The really big surprise that nobody appreciated even in 1938 (though Meitner knew the mass deficits from binding fell off with heavy atoms) was that heavy nuclei are unstable toward fission because of the short range of the strong force (which itself, as a force, was not appreciated). E=mc^2 and the falling mass deficit is not an explanation, but only a measurement of this oddity. When a large nucleus is deformed the strong force can be overwhelmed like a snowball on a mountainside pushed over an obstruction to create an avalanche. All the power comes from the fact that all large nuclei are like avalanches waiting to happen, with the net energy stored inside them (from electromagnetic repulsion). That energy has been stored since the large atoms were made in neutron star collisions or supernovae (it's stored gravitational energy ultimately). The neutron is is a mere trigger to get past the binding strong force and let the longer-range electromagnetic force push the nuclear halves apart, and release energy from this push.

In bombs, all the nuclear material is together in order to maximize the rate of fission. In nuclear power plants, the uranium is contained in small pellets roughly the size of a pencil eraser, which are wrapped in ceramic and put in fuel rods with tons of water and moderator between each fuel rod. This is why a nuclear accident is called a "Meltdown," because the core of the plant literally melts into a pile of sludge. The explosion at Fukushima was actually caused by a design flaw that resulted in hydrogen buildup, which then ignited, and only was an issue in the first place because of a freaking *tsunami*.

Essentially, when you heat something up, it first becomes less efficient, and then becomes much more efficient. Modern nuclear reactors operate at a temperature that assures the if they were to overheat, the fuel would lose efficiency until it stopped heating up, at which point the reaction can be controlled and brought back to safer levels. The plant at Chernobyl operated on the other side of that bell curve, so it heated up exponentially and there really was nothing left to do but run.

I remember first learning about the physics theory behind nuclear fission and the literal goosebumps of horror I got. Each U235 atom split releases around 202.8 MeV, which is the energy equivalent in Joules of 203 electron charges. In comparison, that is roughly several dozen to a hundred times more energy released per event compared to detonating TNT.
Now imagine an exponential chain reaction of this much energy, and it's not hard to imagine the horrendous mushroom-shaped clouds we've come to know. One step further is the hydrogen bomb, where the nuclear fission reaction is used to create the conditions for the second (and even third stage) of a fusion bomb, which is various factors more powerful than a fission bomb.

Weapons are "easier" to make than energy harnessing facilities, because nuclear reactors using fission to tap energy require a supercritical chain reaction (1 fission event triggers exactly 1 other fission event), whereas bombs can just let it go on uncrontrollably. The reason that the reaction can even be kept at a supercritical rate with Uranium is because it has an inherent delay in the chain reaction, making it possible to reverse/stop the reaction using the rods nuclear reactors are known to have, which absorb neutrons to halt or reduce the chain reaction when needed.

Fusion energy is theoretically possible by creating and magnetically controlling a plasma in a 30x30x30m toroid chamber, where the weight equivalent of a post stamp's worth of deuterium-tritium is brought to 150 million degrees kelvin to create self-sustaining fusion conditions. In this type of reactor, a meltdown is impossible because of the extremely small amount of matter being superheated. This theory is at the basis of what the global scientific community is attempting in the ITER project in France.

Balancing on a knife edge -- not really, or at least not exactly as unstable as you might think. First, there are mechanisms that slow the reaction, producing negative feedback. For example, if the reaction increases the material may expand, expanded material is less dense and this causes increase in critical mass and slowing down of the reaction (keeping steady state). Second, the drawing might give an impression that you split an atom and the neutrons immediately hit two more atoms. This is what is called prompt criticality and you want that in a bomb. In a nuclear reactor this is all built so that neutrons given off can't sustain the reaction by themselves. The reaction to be sustained must be reinforced with neutrons that have already left the radioactive material, got slowed down outside (for example in moderator) and only when it is slowed down some of it comes back and only then provides necessary extra neutrons to keep the reaction. This process means that any exponential increase in the reaction will be greatly slowed down to a speed that is much easier to control.
The issue with Chernobyl RMBK reactor was that it had negative void coefficient meaning if it got too hot, the steam voids in water would actually increase reaction rate rather than decreasing it. And this only in rather extreme situation. In normal operation the reactor, even the RBMK, is pretty good at balancing itself without need for any external input.

There may be safety concerns, but the nuclear reaction itself is solved science.

# Impacts of the 2011 Japan Earthquake on Earth rotation.

The March 11th,2011 magnitude 9.0 earthquake in Japan may have shortened the length of each Earth day and shifted its axis. Due to the earthquake changing the distribution of Earth's mass, the Japanese earthquake should have caused Earth to rotate a bit faster, shortening the length of the day by about 1.8 microseconds (a microsecond is one millionth of a second).The Japan quake should have shifted the position of Earth's figure axis (the axis about which Earth's mass is balanced) by about 17 centimeters (6.5 inches), towards 133 degrees east longitude. Earth's figure axis should not be confused with its north-south axis; they are offset by about 10 meters (about 33 feet). This shift in Earth's figure axis will cause Earth to wobble a bit differently as it rotates, but it will not cause a shift of Earth's axis in space—only external forces such as the gravitational attraction of the sun, moon and planets can do that.Earth's rotation changes all the time as a result of not only earthquakes, but also the much larger effects of changes in atmospheric winds and oceanic currents. "Over the course of a year, the length of the day increases and decreases by about a millisecond, or about 550 times larger than the change caused by the Japanese earthquake. The position of Earth's figure axis also changes all the time, by about 1 meter (3.3 feet) over the course of a year, or about six times more than the change that should have been caused by the Japan quake." While we can measure the effects of the atmosphere and ocean on Earth's rotation, the effects of earthquakes, at least up until now, have been too small to measure. The computed change in the length of day caused by earthquakes is much smaller than the accuracy with which scientists can currently measure changes in the length of the day. However, since the position of the figure axis can be measured to an accuracy of about 5 centimeters (2 inches), the estimated 17-centimeter shift in the figure axis from the Japan quake may actually be large enough to observe if scientists can adequately remove the larger effects of the atmosphere and ocean from the Earth rotation measurements. Nuclear power Addendum: Nuclear power would be completely impossible without delay neutrons. Delay neutrons are exactly what they sound like. When something fissions they don't always give off their neutrons right away. Some can take seconds (which is basically inifnity time in the atomic world) or even up to several minutes. These make it so your reactor can be controlled by other larger forces as well as neutron forces.

For instance, your material has time to heat up and expand. This causes less material to be in the core region and slow your reaction down...before the delay neutrons hit and create a new neutron generation. There are other feedback mechanisms that operate on these broader timescales as well, but for power plants, that is basically the happs. Delay neutrons make things more easily manageable by removing a pure exponential function in the mix. A reactor would blow itself apart before it ever sustained a true nuclear explosion. Not even the aforementioned Chernobyl explosion was a nuclear one, it was likely a steam explosion cause by a 10000x increase in heat. Estimates put the explosive power at several dozen tons of TNT, which is enough to blow up a building for sure. Steam explosions are no joke!

While I don't disagree with anything factually, I must say that comparing Chernobyl to a nuclear bomb is troublesome.

People believe that nuclear power plants can explode in the same way a bomb would, which is not the case. Chernobyl had what is called prompt criticality, meaning the reaction was self sustaining without the need for delayed neutrons. While bombs also utilize prompt criticality, they don't have the inherent dampers that power stations employ. Chernobyl did not have a nuclear explosion, it had a steam explosion from heat, and the operators had disabled the safety systems, such as relief valves that would have vented the pressure, so the vessel ruptured.

This may seem like a small difference, but it's important. Reactors are not bombs, and presenting them as such is doing a disservice to nuclear science.

He forgot to mention delayed neutrons. You can't use 100% prompt neutrons (neutrons from fission event) to run a reactor because the power would jump from zero power to exploded/molten core almost instantly. Some fraction of neutrons come from the decay of fission products giving you time to control the population of neutrons. Nuclear plant engineers get quite uncomfortable when they hear "prompt critical".
Neutrons also do lots of other stuff other than fission, like bouncing off nuclei, getting captured by any non-fissile nuclei, or just decaying into a proton and electron. If the neutron is fast enough it can throw neutrons from a heavy nuclei.
